You probably won't be interested in this post since you're not
interested i=
n using expert knowledge. 

But what if you used Bayesian probabilities as =
a form of pre-processed
input for your networks? Based on the flop, the car=
ds in your hand,
and the number of other players. You could calculate some =
useful
probabilities relating to how likely you are to win the hand. I am
s=
ure this has been done ad nauseum in poker bots. It is just my first
instin=
ct.

Also you could use the historical probabilities of how often a given
p=
layer bluffs, to tailor strategies dynamically for a live game.

--Shane

-=
-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "lars_v_hansen" <lvh@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Everyon=
e
> 
> My name is Lars and I am a student at Department of Computer Science=
,
> University of Aarhus, Denmark. I am writing my Master Thesis with my
> =
good friend Mathias who is also a student here ;-). As you probably
> alrea=
dy noticed this thesis is about poker (Texas Hold'em) and GAs.
> 
> The pro=
ject is (like many others) inspired by D. Fogels Blondie24 and
> we would l=
ike to see how well we can learn the ANN players to play
> poker without pr=
esenting them with explicit expert knowledge about eg.
> how many better st=
raights exsists than mine (J. Noble does this).
> 
> We have the poker fram=
ework and the standard GA with elitism. 
> 
> 
> We would like for those of=
 you that are interested in our project to
> see the following implementati=
on details.
> 
> The framework:
> It is coded in Java and has a couple og i=
nterfaces such that we can
> switch player types between our different ANN =
players, players based
> primarily on pot-odds and of course our own "human=
-player-gui".
> 
> We just recently discovered NEAT (sadly :-() and yesterd=
ay we finished
> a new player based on jNEAT. The player ANN takes the foll=
owing
> inputs:
> 
> 1 pot / bet
> 1 position
> 9 player actions this round=

> 9 player passive / aggressive index
> 9 player tight / loose index
> 2 s=
uit count (4 or 5 siuted cards)
> 2 connector count (4 or 5 connected cards=
)
> 4 card associations (pair, two pairs, three of a kind, four of a kind)
=
> 2 hole cards in use ( are we using 1 or 2 hole cards in our hand?)
> 3 ga=
me stage (FLOP/TURN/RIVER)
> 
> TOTAL: 45 input neurons
> 
> We actually st=
arted out with an ANN that had 52 neurons for the cards
> and a constant k =
it could add to the hole cards (Like the kings in
> Blondie24). But we real=
ised that it would be very had if not
> impossible for the ANN to "see" the=
 good hands and separate them from
> the bad ones. Therefore we decided to =
show the ANN that certain hands
> appeard (or almost appeard in connector /=
 suit count). This also
> dramaticaly reduced the number of inputs.
> 
> Th=
e outputs from the ANN are straight forward:
> 3 neurons:
> FOLD | CALL | B=
ET/RAISE
> 
> The output neuron that is activated the most is the action we=
 choose
> if it is "legal" at the table otherwise we choose the second most=

> activated and so on.
> 
> 
> The fitness of the players:
> We have exper=
imented with several settings but the best we have right
> now is this: 
> =

> The 50 players play against each other and a pot-odds-player
> (PO-playe=
r) - five of each at each table. They play 600 hands but not
> at one table=
 only - we mix them between the tables five times such
> that they get to m=
eet different individuals from the entire
> population.
> The reason we hav=
e the PO-players at each table is for the players to
> be forced to learn f=
aster and play tighter from the very beginning.
> 
> Since we have discover=
ed NEAT we are more open to leaving the
> PO-players and going back to stri=
ct competitive co-evolution between
> our own individuals. We also consider=
 expanding the population to
> about 200. But still the problem is here tha=
t the weak players at one
> table can make only slightly better players at =
the same table look
> very strong compared to really strong players actuall=
y competing and
> not winning much at another table. Another option is to m=
ake a
> tournament or like Darse Billings [Alberta GAMES group] suggests: L=
et
> each player take the same position at the table and see who is the
> b=
est over-all player.
> 
> A major concern is the fitness: We have talked ab=
out it for hours and
> days but we always come back to the cash of the play=
er. If we cannot
> apply expert knowledge - we cannot think of anything els=
e than the
> amount earned after x hands.
> 
> We would like comments on th=
e above and if possible we would like some
> suggestions or answers to the =
following questions:
> 
> 1) Is it possible to achieve results with a 45->N=
->3 ANN in NEAT?
> 
> 2) Any general comments regarding the population size=
 for the above
> ANN?
> 
> 3) Any parameters we should put in a particular =
favourable setting?
> 
> We use these settings recommended from a NEAT webs=
ite:

Thesis with my

 probably

 and
> we would like to see how well we can learn the ANN players to play
>=
 poker without presenting them with explicit expert knowledge about eg.

ow many better straights exsists than mine (J. Noble does this).

ve the poker framework and the standard GA with elitism.

like for those of you that are interested in our project to

wing implementation details.

> The framework:

has a couple og interfaces such that we can
> switch player types between o=
ur different ANN players, players based
> primarily on pot-odds and of cour=
se our own "human-player-gui".
> 
> We just recently discovered NEAT (sadly=
 :-() and yesterday we finished
> a new player based on jNEAT. The player A=
NN takes the following inputs:
> 
> 1 pot / bet
> 1 position
> 9 player act=
ions this round

> 9 player tight / lo=
ose index
> 2 suit count (4 or 5 siuted cards)
> 2 connector count (4 or 5 =
connected cards)
> 4 card associations (pair, two pairs, three of a kind, f=
our of a kind)
> 2 hole cards in use ( are we using 1 or 2 hole cards in ou=
r hand?)
> 3 game stage (FLOP/TURN/RIVER)

> TOTAL: 45 input neurons
> 
>=
 We actually started out with an ANN that had 52 neurons for the cards
> an=
d a constant k it could add to the hole cards (Like the kings in
> Blondie2=
4). But we realised that it would be very had if not
> impossible for the A=
NN to "see" the good hands and separate them from
> the bad ones. Therefore=
 we decided to show the ANN that certain hands
> appeard (or almost appeard=
 in connector / suit count). This also
> dramaticaly reduced the number of =
inputs.
> 
> The outputs from the ANN are straight forward:
> 3 neurons:
> =
FOLD | CALL | BET/RAISE
> 
> The output neuron that is activated the most i=
s the action we choose
> if it is "legal" at the table otherwise we choose =
the second most
> activated and so on.
> 
> 
> The fitness of the players:
=
> We have experimented with several settings but the best we have right
> n=
ow is this: 
> 
> The 50 players play against each other and a pot-odds-pla=
yer
> (PO-player) - five of each at each table. They play 600 hands but not=

> at one table only - we mix them between the tables five times such
> tha=
t they get to meet different individuals from the entire population.
> The =
reason we have the PO-players at each table is for the players to
> be forc=
ed to learn faster and play tighter from the very beginning.
> 
> Since we =
have discovered NEAT we are more open to leaving the
> PO-players and going=
 back to strict competitive co-evolution between
> our own individuals. We =
also consider expanding the population to
> about 200. But still the proble=
m is here that the weak players at one
> table can make only slightly bette=
r players at the same table look
> very strong compared to really strong pl=
ayers actually competing and
> not winning much at another table. Another o=
ption is to make a
> tournament or like Darse Billings [Alberta GAMES group=
] suggests: Let
> each player take the same position at the table and see w=
ho is the
> best over-all player.
> 
> A major concern is the fitness: We h=
ave talked about it for hours and
> days but we always come back to the cas=
h of the player. If we cannot
> apply expert knowledge - we cannot think of=
 anything else than the
> amount earned after x hands.
> 
> We would like c=
omments on the above and if possible we would like some

swers to the following questions:

> 1) Is it possible to achieve results=
 with a 45->N->3 ANN in NEAT?
>

pulation size for the above ANN?

it_mutation_power =3D 1;
